clusters.title: Fire prompts evacuations at U.N. climate talks in Brazil; 13 suffer smoke inhalation
clusters.neutral_headline: Fire at COP30 Climate Talks Prompts Evacuations

items.title: Fire prompts evacuations at U.N. climate talks in Brazil; 13 suffer smoke inhalation
items.standfirst: Officials say a fire that spread through pavilions being used for U.N. climate talks in Brazil has prompted evacuations on the next-to-last day of the conference.
items.content: Officials say a fire that spread through pavilions being used for U.N. climate talks in Brazil has prompted evacuations on the next-to-last day of the conference. (Image credit: Catherine Ellis)

items.title: Fire breaks out at COP30 climate talks, suspending key negotiations
items.standfirst: A fire tore through the COP30 summit venue in Brazil on Thursday, burning part of the roof and forcing a panicked evacuation as talks entered a critical phase. The blaze hit pavilions at the Belem site, the third major incident after Indigenous protesters stormed and later blockaded the venue.
items.content: A fire tore through the COP30 summit venue in Brazil on Thursday, burning part of the roof and forcing a panicked evacuation as talks entered a critical phase. The blaze hit pavilions at the Belem site, the third major incident after Indigenous protesters stormed and later blockaded the venue.

items.title: 'Huge columns of smoke': BBC at the scene of fire at COP30

items.content: Climate Editor Justin Rowlatt was at the UN climate talks in Brazil when a fire broke out.

items.title: COP30 attendees in Brazil forced to evacuate pavilion following fire
items.standfirst: Officials say the fire was contained within six minutes, and 13 attendees were treated for smoke inhalation.
items.content: Officials say the fire was contained within six minutes, and 13 attendees were treated for smoke inhalation.

items.title: COP30 evacuated as fire erupts during UN climate talks in Brazil
items.standfirst: A fire broke out at a COP30 climate conference venue in Belem, Brazil, prompting the evacuation of panicked delegates.
items.content: A fire broke out at a COP30 climate conference venue in Belem, Brazil, prompting the evacuation of panicked delegates.

items.title: COP30 climate talks evacuated after fire breaks out
items.standfirst: Thousands of people are attending the UN climate talks in Brazil.
items.content: Thousands of people are attending the UN climate talks in Brazil.

ai_summary: A fire broke out at the COP30 climate conference venue in Belem, Brazil.
The fire prompted evacuations of attendees during the UN climate talks.
Thirteen attendees were treated for smoke inhalation after the fire.
The fire occurred on the next-to-last day of the conference.
The fire was contained within six minutes, according to officials.

clusters.title: Frida Kahlo self-portrait sells for $54.7 million, sets new record for female artists
clusters.neutral_headline: Frida Kahlo Self-Portrait Sells for $54.7 Million

items.title: Frida Kahlo self-portrait sells for $54.7 million, sets new record for female artists
items.standfirst: Frida Kahlo’s 1940 self-portrait “El sueño (La cama)” sold for $54.66 million in New York on Thursday, Sotheby’s said, setting a record for the most expensive painting by a woman.
items.content: Frida Kahlo’s 1940 self-portrait “El sueño (La cama)” sold for $54.66 million in New York on Thursday, Sotheby’s said, setting a record for the most expensive painting by a woman.

items.title: Frida Kahlo self-portrait sells for $54.7 million, shattering record for female artists
items.standfirst: A 1940 self-portrait by Frida Kahlo has sold for $54.7 million and made auction history at Sotheby's in New York.
items.content: A 1940 self-portrait by Frida Kahlo has sold for $54.7 million and made auction history at Sotheby's in New York.

items.title: Frida Kahlo self-portrait sells for $54.7m to set new auction record for a female artist
items.standfirst: The 1940 painting of Kahlo asleep in bed has surpassed the record set by the $44.4m sale of Georgia O’Keeffe’s Jimson Weed/White Flower No. 1 in 2014A 1940 self-portrait by famed Mexican artist Frida Kahlo has sold for $54.7m (£41.8m, A$84.7m) at a New York art auction, setting a new top sale price for a work by any female artist.El sueño (La cama), or The Dream (The Bed), which depicts Kahlo asleep in a bed with a smiling skeleton wrapped in dynamite on the canopy above her, sold on Thursday night at a Sotheby’s auction of surrealist art after four minutes of bidding. Continue reading...
items.content: The 1940 painting of Kahlo asleep in bed has surpassed the record set by the $44.4m sale of Georgia O’Keeffe’s Jimson Weed/White Flower No. 1 in 2014A 1940 self-portrait by famed Mexican artist Frida Kahlo has sold for $54.7m (£41.8m, A$84.7m) at a New York art auction, setting a new top sale price for a work by any female artist.El sueño (La cama), or The Dream (The Bed), which depicts Kahlo asleep in a bed with a smiling skeleton wrapped in dynamite on the canopy above her, sold on Thursday night at a Sotheby’s auction of surrealist art after four minutes of bidding. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Frida Kahlo's self-portrait "El sueño (La cama)" sold for $54.7 million.
The sale set a new record for the most expensive painting by a woman.
The painting was sold at a Sotheby's auction in New York.
The painting depicts Kahlo asleep in bed with a skeleton above her.
The sale surpassed the previous record set by Georgia O'Keeffe.

items.title: US-backed plan would hand eastern Donbas to Russia, Zelensky calls for 'dignified peace'
items.standfirst: The plan put forward by the United States to end the war in Ukraine calls, among other measures, for Kyiv to cede the eastern Donbas region to Russia. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday appealed for a “dignified peace,” as Russia claimed to have captured the stronghold of Kupyansk.
items.content: The plan put forward by the United States to end the war in Ukraine calls, among other measures, for Kyiv to cede the eastern Donbas region to Russia. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday appealed for a “dignified peace,” as Russia claimed to have captured the stronghold of Kupyansk.

clusters.title: CDC website changes to include false claim about autism and vaccines
clusters.neutral_headline: CDC Website Changes Include False Autism Claim

items.title: CDC website changes to include false claim about autism and vaccines
items.standfirst: Multiple CDC officials familiar with the situation said the change was made by political appointees without input from relevant agency staffers.
items.content: Multiple CDC officials familiar with the situation said the change was made by political appointees without input from relevant agency staffers.

items.title: CDC website changed to include false claim about autism and vaccines
items.standfirst: A page of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website was changed to include a false claim about autism and vaccines. Multiple CDC officials familiar with the situation said the change was made by political appointees inside the Department of Health and Human Services without input from relevant agency staffers. Dr. Jon LaPook has details.
items.content: A page of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website was changed to include a false claim about autism and vaccines. Multiple CDC officials familiar with the situation said the change was made by political appointees inside the Department of Health and Human Services without input from relevant agency staffers. Dr. Jon LaPook has details.

items.title: CDC website altered to reflect RFK Jr’s belief in link between vaccines and autism
items.standfirst: Public health and autism specialists roundly condemn alteration to the ‘vaccine safety’ webpageA Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website has been changed to reflect the belief of Robert F Kennedy Jr, the US health and human services secretary, that there is a link between vaccines and autism, a view flatly contradicted by experts and scientifically validated studies.Public health and autism specialists roundly condemned the alteration to the CDC’s “vaccine safety” webpage, after it was changed to read: “The statement ‘Vaccines do not cause autism’ is not an evidence-based claim.” Continue reading...
items.content: Public health and autism specialists roundly condemn alteration to the ‘vaccine safety’ webpageA Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website has been changed to reflect the belief of Robert F Kennedy Jr, the US health and human services secretary, that there is a link between vaccines and autism, a view flatly contradicted by experts and scientifically validated studies.Public health and autism specialists roundly condemned the alteration to the CDC’s “vaccine safety” webpage, after it was changed to read: “The statement ‘Vaccines do not cause autism’ is not an evidence-based claim.” Continue reading...

items.title: The CDC revives debunked 'link' between childhood vaccines and autism
items.standfirst: A Centers for Disease Control and Prevention webpage that previously stated "Vaccines do not cause autism" has been changed to cast doubt on the scientific research that supports the finding.
items.content: A Centers for Disease Control and Prevention webpage that previously stated "Vaccines do not cause autism" has been changed to cast doubt on the scientific research that supports the finding.(Image credit: Ben Hendren)

ai_summary: The CDC website was changed to include a false claim about autism and vaccines.
Multiple CDC officials said the change was made by political appointees.
The change reflects the belief of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
Public health specialists condemned the alteration to the webpage.
The original statement "Vaccines do not cause autism" was altered.

items.title: Rapper Pras Michel sentenced to 14 years in prison over illegal donations to Obama campaign
items.standfirst: Grammy-winning rapper Prakazrel “Pras” Michel of the Fugees was sentenced on Thursday to 14 years in prison for a case in which he was convicted of illegally funneling millions of dollars in foreign contributions to former President Barack Obama’s 2012 reelection campaign.
items.content: Grammy-winning rapper Prakazrel “Pras” Michel of the Fugees was sentenced on Thursday to 14 years in prison for a case in which he was convicted of illegally funneling millions of dollars in foreign contributions to former President Barack Obama’s 2012 reelection campaign.

items.title: Fugees rapper Pras sentenced to 14 years in prison over illegal donations to Obama campaign
items.standfirst: Prakazrel ‘Pras’ Michel was convicted in 2023 after a trial that included testimony from actor Leonardo DiCaprio and former US attorney general Jeff SessionsThe Grammy-winning rapper Prakazrel “Pras” Michel of the Fugees has been sentenced to 14 years in prison for a case in which he was convicted of illegally funnelling millions of dollars in foreign contributions to former US president Barack Obama’s 2012 reelection campaign.Michel, 52, declined to address the court before US district judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly sentenced him on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Prakazrel ‘Pras’ Michel was convicted in 2023 after a trial that included testimony from actor Leonardo DiCaprio and former US attorney general Jeff SessionsThe Grammy-winning rapper Prakazrel “Pras” Michel of the Fugees has been sentenced to 14 years in prison for a case in which he was convicted of illegally funnelling millions of dollars in foreign contributions to former US president Barack Obama’s 2012 reelection campaign.Michel, 52, declined to address the court before US district judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly sentenced him on Thursday. Continue reading...

items.title: Fugees rapper Pras Michel sentenced to 14 years in prison over illegal donations to Obama campaign

ai_summary: Rapper Pras Michel of the Fugees was sentenced to 14 years in prison.
He was convicted of illegally funneling foreign contributions.
The contributions were made to the 2012 Obama campaign.
The sentencing occurred on Thursday.
Michel declined to address the court before sentencing.

items.title: US added 119,000 jobs in September in report delayed by federal shutdown
items.standfirst: Unemployment rate hits 4.4%, its highest level since 2021, and government has said no October report will be issuedThe US jobs market added 119,000 jobs in September, according to the latest monthly jobs report, which was delayed by six weeks due to the shutdown of the federal government.Amid heightened uncertainty surrounding the strength of the US economy, the much-anticipated reading was higher than the 51,000 jobs expected by analysts to be added in September. Continue reading...
items.content: Unemployment rate hits 4.4%, its highest level since 2021, and government has said no October report will be issuedThe US jobs market added 119,000 jobs in September, according to the latest monthly jobs report, which was delayed by six weeks due to the shutdown of the federal government.Amid heightened uncertainty surrounding the strength of the US economy, the much-anticipated reading was higher than the 51,000 jobs expected by analysts to be added in September. The unemployment rate hit 4.4%, its highest since 2021.
The Chicago Fed president said the report complicates rate cut decisions.
The government has said no October report will be issued.

items.title: Cristiano Ronaldo attends White House meeting and dinner with Donald Trump

items.content: Cristiano Ronaldo and his future-wife Georgia were at the White House on November 18 as President Donald Trump hosted a glitzy dinner to honor Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

items.title: U.S. retiree freed after years jailed in Saudi Arabia for critical tweets
items.standfirst: A U.S. retiree held in Saudi Arabia over critical tweets has been freed months ahead of schedule, his son said, a day after Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman appeared hand in hand with President Donald Trump at the White House."Our family is overjoyed that, after four long years, our father, Saad Almadi, is finally on his way home," his family said in a statement his son Ibrahim posted Wednesday on X. Riyadh authorities jailed and then banned Saad Almadi, 75, from leaving the country two years ag
items.content: A U.S. retiree held in Saudi Arabia over critical tweets has been freed months ahead of schedule, his son said, a day after Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman appeared hand in hand with President Donald Trump at the White House."Our family is overjoyed that, after four long years, our father, Saad Almadi, is finally on his way home," his family said in a statement his son Ibrahim posted Wednesday on X. Riyadh authorities jailed and then banned Saad Almadi, 75, from leaving the country two years ag

items.title: Saudi Arabia releases US retiree jailed over critical tweets
items.standfirst: Saad Almadi’s family thanks Trump and state department as announcement comes after meeting with crown princeSaudi Arabia has agreed to allow US citizen Saad Almadi to return home to Florida, five months ahead of the scheduled lifting of travel restrictions and a day after Saudi crown prince and prime minister Mohammed bin Salman met Donald Trump at the White House.Almadi, 75, was sentenced to 19 years of incarceration in the kingdom in 2021 after he wrote 14 tweets critical of the Riyadh government. Two years later, the charges were reduced to so-called “cyber crimes” and he was sentenced to a 30-year ban on leaving Saudi Arabia. Continue reading...
items.content: Saad Almadi’s family thanks Trump and state department as announcement comes after meeting with crown princeSaudi Arabia has agreed to allow US citizen Saad Almadi to return home to Florida, five months ahead of the scheduled lifting of travel restrictions and a day after Saudi crown prince and prime minister Mohammed bin Salman met Donald Trump at the White House.Almadi, 75, was sentenced to 19 years of incarceration in the kingdom in 2021 after he wrote 14 tweets critical of the Riyadh government. Two years later, the charges were reduced to so-called “cyber crimes” and he was sentenced to a 30-year ban on leaving Saudi Arabia. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump considers order to override state regulations on artificial intelligence
items.standfirst: The Trump White House is reportedly drafting an executive order that would override state regulations on artificial intelligence. The order would establish a task force inside the Justice Department to sue, and potentially withhold federal funding from, states that pass their own AI laws. Geoff…
items.content: The Trump White House is reportedly drafting an executive order that would override state regulations on artificial intelligence. The order would establish a task force inside the Justice Department to sue, and potentially withhold federal funding from, states that pass their own AI laws. Geoff…

items.title: Trump Takes Aim at State AI Laws in Draft Executive Order
items.standfirst: The draft order, obtained by WIRED, instructs the US Justice Department to sue states that pass laws regulating AI.
items.content: The draft order, obtained by WIRED, instructs the US Justice Department to sue states that pass laws regulating AI.

ai_summary: Trump is reportedly drafting an executive order to override state AI regulations.
The order would establish a Justice Department task force to sue states.
The task force could potentially withhold federal funding from non-compliant states.
The order was obtained by Wired, which reported on its contents.
The order targets states passing their own laws regulating artificial intelligence.

clusters.title: What’s in the files of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein?
clusters.neutral_headline: US to Release Epstein Files After Trump Signs Bill

items.title: What’s in the files of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein?
items.standfirst: US Congress votes to release more Department of Justice files on the Epstein case.
items.content: US Congress votes to release more Department of Justice files on the Epstein case.

items.title: Trump signs bill ordering US justice department to release Epstein files
items.standfirst: The bill gives the US Justice Department 30 days to release all the files in a searchable format.
items.content: The bill gives the US Justice Department 30 days to release all the files in a searchable format.

ai_summary: Congress voted to release more Department of Justice files on Epstein.
The US Justice Department has 30 days to release all files.
The files will be released in a searchable format.
The bill was signed by former President Trump.
The files relate to the Jeffrey Epstein case.

clusters.title: US adds 119,000 jobs in September but unemployment hits four-year peak
clusters.neutral_headline: US Job Growth Slows, Unemployment Rate Rises

items.title: US adds 119,000 jobs in September but unemployment hits four-year peak
items.standfirst: Figures complicate Fed decision on rates next month
items.content: Figures complicate Fed decision on rates next month

items.title: US economy adds 119,000 jobs in September as unemployment rate rises
items.standfirst: The unemployment rate rose to 4.4 percent as the labour market cools.
items.content: The unemployment rate rose to 4.4 percent as the labour market cools.

ai_summary: The US economy added 119,000 jobs in September.
The unemployment rate rose to 4.4 percent.
The job growth figures complicate the Federal Reserve's rate decision.
The figures were released in September.
The labor market is showing signs of cooling.

clusters.title: Nigerian separatist leader sentenced to life for terrorism
clusters.neutral_headline: Nigerian Separatist Leader Sentenced to Life in Prison

items.title: Nigerian separatist leader sentenced to life for terrorism
items.standfirst: Nnamdi Kanu is found guilty of inciting violence as part of his campaign for a separate state in south-east Nigeria.
items.content: Nnamdi Kanu is found guilty of inciting violence as part of his campaign for a separate state in south-east Nigeria.

items.title: Biafran separatist leader sentenced to life on terrorism charges by Nigerian court
items.standfirst: Judge says Nnamdi Kanu used his Indigenous People of Biafra group to incite attacks on security officials and civiliansThe Biafran separatist leader Nnamdi Kanu has been sentenced to life in prison on terrorism-related charges by a court in the Nigerian capital, Abuja.Judge James Omotosho said prosecutors had shown that Kanu, who also holds British citizenship, had used his Indigenous People of Biafra group (Ipob) to incite attacks on security officials and civilians in south-east Nigeria and during anti-police protests in Lagos. Continue reading...
items.content: Judge says Nnamdi Kanu used his Indigenous People of Biafra group to incite attacks on security officials and civiliansThe Biafran separatist leader Nnamdi Kanu has been sentenced to life in prison on terrorism-related charges by a court in the Nigerian capital, Abuja.Judge James Omotosho said prosecutors had shown that Kanu, who also holds British citizenship, had used his Indigenous People of Biafra group (Ipob) to incite attacks on security officials and civilians in south-east Nigeria and during anti-police protests in Lagos. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nnamdi Kanu was sentenced to life for terrorism charges.
The court found Kanu guilty of inciting violence.
Kanu's group, IPOB, was used to incite attacks.
Attacks were directed at security officials and civilians.
Kanu also holds British citizenship.

clusters.title: Trump, Epstein and the files: What we know and what happens next
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump, Epstein and the files: What we know and what happens next

items.title: Trump, Epstein and the files: What we know and what happens next
items.standfirst: In a stunning reversal Wednesday, US President Donald Trump signed a bill mandating the release of government files on convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The documents could shed light on the full extent of Epstein’s criminal network and connections to the powerful, though experts warn redactions and legal limits may leave many details in the dark.
items.content: In a stunning reversal Wednesday, US President Donald Trump signed a bill mandating the release of government files on convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The documents could shed light on the full extent of Epstein’s criminal network and connections to the powerful, though experts warn redactions and legal limits may leave many details in the dark.

items.title: What do we know about the Epstein files?
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump has approved a bill that orders the release of material from investigations into Epstein, the late sex offender.
items.content: US President Donald Trump has approved a bill that orders the release of material from investigations into Epstein, the late sex offender.

ai_summary: Former President Trump signed a bill mandating release of government files.
The files concern convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
Documents could reveal the extent of Epstein's criminal network.
Experts warn redactions and legal limits may obscure details.
The bill orders the release of material from investigations into Epstein.
